messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

Objective: Execute sub task step: 10. Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire system. This includes unit tests, integration tests, and performance tests. Ensure that all features work correctly and that the system can handle a large number of URLs and user accounts. Also, check the system's performance under heavy load and optimize as necessary..

 Note: Condition any new code files on the existing code files: ['app.py', 'requirements.txt', 'test_app.py']. Fully implement these features in the code, no placeholders. You can now optionally view the existing files if you need to view them to complete the current task step. You have a limited context window so be selective about which files you view, only view the files you think you might need to view.

Respond now only with a function call of one of the following functions provided: `sub_task_step_complete`, `view_files`, `run_python_file`, `pytest_files`, `write_files`, `delete_files`, and if you want to output code only use the `write_files` function to output code.

{
  "files_and_contents": [
    {
      "file_path": "test_app.py",
      "file_contents": "import pytest
import app
import time

@pytest.fixture
def client():
	app.app.config['TESTING'] = True
	with app.app.test_client() as client:
		yield client


def test_register_login(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_shorten_url(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	assert len(short_url) == 6


def test_redirect_url(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	response = client.get(f'/{short_url}')
	assert response.status_code == 302


def test_analytics(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	response = client.get(f'/analytics/{short_url}')
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_admin(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'admin', 'password': 'admin'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'admin', 'password': 'admin'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.get('/admin')
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_cache(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	start_time = time.time()
	for _ in range(100):
		response = client.get(f'/{short_url}')
		assert response.status_code == 302
	end_time = time.time()
	assert end_time - start_time < 1, 'Cache is not working properly'
"
    }
  ]
}

steps: 1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Flask application and set up the basic structure with the necessary files and folders. This includes the main application file (app.py), a folder for templates, a folder for static files, and a folder for tests. Also, create a requirements.txt file to list all the necessary dependencies for the project. Write a test to ensure that the Flask application is set up correctly and can run without errors.

2. Implement the URL shortening feature. Create a new route in the Flask application that accepts a POST request with a URL to be shortened. The route should validate the URL, generate a unique shortened URL, and return it to the user. The shortened URLs should be stored in an in-memory dictionary for now. Write tests to ensure that the URL shortening feature works correctly, including tests for invalid URLs and duplicate URLs.

3. Implement the redirection feature. Create another route in the Flask application that accepts a GET request with a shortened URL. The route should look up the original URL from the in-memory dictionary and redirect the user to it. If the shortened URL is not found, the route should return a 404 error. Write tests to ensure that the redirection feature works correctly, including tests for non-existent shortened URLs.

4. Implement the analytics feature. Each time a shortened URL is accessed, the system should record the date/time of the access and the geographical location of the user. This data should be stored in the in-memory dictionary along with the original URL. Create a new route that accepts a GET request with a shortened URL and returns the analytics data for that URL. Write tests to ensure that the analytics feature works correctly, including tests for non-existent shortened URLs.

5. Implement the user accounts feature. Users should be able to create an account with a username and password. The account data should be stored in the in-memory dictionary. Create routes for user registration and login. After logging in, users should be able to view, edit, and delete their shortened URLs. Write tests to ensure that the user accounts feature works correctly, including tests for duplicate usernames and incorrect passwords.

6. Implement the admin dashboard feature. Administrators should be able to view all shortened URLs and user accounts. They should also be able to delete any URL or user account. Create a new route for the admin dashboard that is only accessible to administrators. Write tests to ensure that the admin dashboard feature works correctly, including tests for unauthorized access.

7. Implement the URL expiration feature. Users should be able to set an expiration date/time for their shortened URLs. After the expiration date/time, the shortened URL should no longer redirect to the original URL. Modify the redirection route to check the expiration date/time before redirecting. Write tests to ensure that the URL expiration feature works correctly, including tests for expired URLs.

8. Refactor the in-memory dictionary to a more suitable data structure. The current in-memory dictionary is not suitable for a large number of URLs and user accounts. Consider using a more efficient data structure, such as a hash table or a trie. Write tests to ensure that the new data structure works correctly and improves the performance of the system.

9. Implement a caching mechanism to improve the performance of the system. Frequently accessed URLs should be stored in a cache to reduce the number of lookups in the data structure. Consider using a least recently used (LRU) cache for this purpose. Write tests to ensure that the caching mechanism works correctly and improves the performance of the system.

10. Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire system. This includes unit tests, integration tests, and performance tests. Ensure that all features work correctly and that the system can handle a large number of URLs and user accounts. Also, check the system's performance under heavy load and optimize as necessary.
step: 10. Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire system. This includes unit tests, integration tests, and performance tests. Ensure that all features work correctly and that the system can handle a large number of URLs and user accounts. Also, check the system's performance under heavy load and optimize as necessary.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
### **Online URL Shortening Service**

**Overview**:
A service that allows users to submit long URLs and then receive a shortened version of that URL for ease of sharing.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

1. **URL Shortening**:
   - [ ] 1.1. Users can input a URL to be shortened.
   - [ ] 1.2. The system validates that the URL is active and legitimate.
   - [ ] 1.3. The system generates a unique shortened URL.
   - [ ] 1.4. Users can choose custom short links (subject to availability).

2. **Redirection**:
   - [ ] 2.1. Accessing the shortened URL redirects to the original URL.

3. **Analytics**:
   - [ ] 3.1. Users can view statistics about their shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 3.2. View number of clicks.
   - [ ] 3.3. View date/time of each click.
   - [ ] 3.4. View geographical location of the clicker.

4. **User Accounts**:
   - [ ] 4.1. Users can create accounts.
   - [ ] 4.2. Account holders can view all their shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 4.3. Account holders can edit or delete their shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 4.4. Account holders can view analytics for all their shortened URLs.

5. **Admin Dashboard**:
   - [ ] 5.1. Administrators can view all shortened URLs.
   - [ ] 5.2. Administrators can delete any URL or user account.
   - [ ] 5.3. Administrators can monitor system performance and analytics.

6. **Expiration**:
   - [ ] 6.1. Users can set an expiration date/time for the shortened URL.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.

{
  "files_and_contents": [
    {
      "file_path": "test_app.py",
      "file_contents": "import pytest
import app
import time

@pytest.fixture
def client():
	app.app.config['TESTING'] = True
	with app.app.test_client() as client:
		yield client


def test_register_login(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_shorten_url(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	assert len(short_url) == 6


def test_redirect_url(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	response = client.get(f'/{short_url}')
	assert response.status_code == 302


def test_analytics(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	response = client.get(f'/analytics/{short_url}')
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_admin(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'admin', 'password': 'admin'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'admin', 'password': 'admin'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.get('/admin')
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_cache(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	start_time = time.time()
	for _ in range(100):
		response = client.get(f'/{short_url}')
		assert response.status_code == 302
	end_time = time.time()
	assert end_time - start_time < 1, 'Cache is not working properly'
"
    }
  ]
}

import app
import time

@pytest.fixture
def client():
	app.app.config['TESTING'] = True
	with app.app.test_client() as client:
		yield client


def test_register_login(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test', 'password': 'test'})
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_shorten_url(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test1', 'password': 'test1'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test1', 'password': 'test1'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	short_url = response.get_json()['short_url']
	assert len(short_url) == 6


def test_redirect_url(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test2', 'password': 'test2'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test2', 'password': 'test2'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})

	response = client.get(f'/{short_url}')
	assert response.status_code == 302


def test_analytics(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'test3', 'password': 'test3'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'test3', 'password': 'test3'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/shorten_url', json={'url': 'https://www.google.com'})

	response = client.get(f'/analytics/{short_url}')
	assert response.status_code == 200


def test_admin(client):
	response = client.post('/register', json={'username': 'admin', 'password': 'admin'})
	assert response.status_code == 200
	response = client.post('/login', json={'username': 'admin', 'password': 'admin'})

def test_cache(client):
